text:
This is really interesting - I'm a bit more sceptical about ubiquity of APIs in 2024! Many services have turned off their APIs, or limit them, especially consumer services.

It's still doable though - either via instrumenting a web browser with some LLM help, or I think instrumenting Android apps in a VM would be a possible way to go.

elements.text:
This is really interesting - I'm a bit more sceptical about ubiquity of APIs in 2024! Many services have turned off their APIs, or limit them, especially consumer services.

It's still doable though - either via instrumenting a web browser with some LLM help, or I think instrumenting Android apps in a VM would be a possible way to go.

text: <@U06U4SKA16E> Thanks! :tada: It's true that some large names have turned off or limited their public APIs but on the whole businesses want to get reach and interoperability. It's not clear what the general trend is yet to my mind. And I'd prefer to assume that on the whole companies want to allow their users to access their service/data via API. I'd hope it makes business sense for them. So I'd prefer to politely try the "front door" first rather than just assuming APIs are a lost cause from the get-go.
